prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Because tag-along actions are presumptively appropriate for transfer, the issues that arise concerning these actions are few. There are, however, certain issues that may arise and certain arguments that may he useful to prevent transfer. These issues derive, in large part, from either the requirements for transfer the Panel must consider under the statute or the specific factors used by the Panel to determine if those requirements are met.

Relatedness. Tag-along actions must be related to the actions previously transferred by the Panel. The Panel Rules as amended in 2001 define “tag-along action” as “a civil action pending in district court and involving common questions of fact with actions previously transferred under Section 1407.”[1] If they are not related, they are not potential tag-along actions.

A bright line separating “related” from “non-related” does not exist. The Panel has essentially addressed this question on a case-by-case basis. The Panel has declined to transfer two cases involving claims by a group of persons who had acquired stock in a merger with the claims of other investors.[2] Those claims had previously been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, but the Panel determined that the claims relating to the separate transaction should not be transferred. The Panel noted that “[a]lthough there may be some common questions of fact, the non-common issues clearly predominate.”[3] The Panel has, however, transferred actions of one group of franchisees against a franchisor for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with franchise actions involving a different franchise system.[4] The Panel focused its consideration on the fact that the franchisor was common in each system, and common facts would be involved in the litigation. In another case, the Panel transferred a group of citizen claims to join previously transferred municipal claims.[5] Similarly, the Panel has even transferred claims involving products not included in the transferee court docket.[6] The Panel has rejected arguments that transfer of a tag-along antitrust action should not be ordered when it relates to a different geographic market than that in the actions previously transferred.[7] Similarly, in mass tort litigation relating to an allegedly defective and dangerous vaccination, the Panel rejected the argument of a plaintiff in a single tag-along action that her action was unique because it sought damages for fainting rather than different symptoms in other cases.[8]

The Panel may decline to transfer a potential tag-along case if there appears to be little overlap in the potential processing of the cases by the courts. In one case a securities plaintiff was successful in convincing the Panel that his claims were factually unique, and that he was not pursuing claims similar or related to those previously transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. The Panel accordingly denied transfer as a tag-along action.[9] When it appeared that the plaintiff did, in fact, intend to pursue similar claims and assert similar discovery requests as those in the transferred cases, the Panel ordered transfer.[10]

Even if the actions present similar facts, the Panel may deny transfer if the tag-along case will present sufficient new and burdensome issues so as to make management of the litigation difficult or to make it likely that trial or remand of the previously transferred actions would be delayed.[11]

The Panel may also decline to order transfer of a relatively simple tag-along action where the previously transferred actions are complex. For example, in multidistrict antitrust litigation the Panel has declined to transfer as a tag-along action a simple breach-of-contract claim.[12] As is true for the initial transfer decision, cases do not need to be identical in order to be transferred. The fact that the potential tag-along action includes some different claims is not fatal to transfer.[13]

Similarity of Status. The Panel may be concerned about procedural differences between the potential tag-along case and the cases previously transferred. For example, if the transferred cases are approaching “ready-for-trial” status and remand, transfer of a recently filed identical case may be inappropriate.[14] This factor essentially recognizes that even identical cases may not be suitable for transfer because transfer may not “advance the just and efficient conduct of the actions.”[15] The Panel will specifically consider the status of the actions then pending in the transferee court.[16] If transfer of tag-along actions will “disrupt” the pretrial proceedings in the previously-transferred cases, transfer will be denied.[17] Even aside from disruption, there is an argument essentially akin to mootness where the existing docket is nearing completion. The Panel observed in In re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation:

“When a transferee judge has accomplished essentially all of the primary objectives of centralization under 28 U.S.C. § 1407 and the advantages of transferring a particular tag-along no longer clearly outweigh the disadvantages, then this Panel promotes the interests of effciency and justice by ending the automatic transfer of such cases. Our review of the record indicates that we have reached such a point in the life of this MDL.”[18]

This factor does not give a party in a tag-along case an objection merely that it has not participated in the pretrial proceedings in the transferee court. The Panel has rejected the argument that “catching up” will be unduly difficult where there is not great disparity in the overall status of the cases.[19] The Panel has also considered the fact that a party objecting to transfer of a tag-along action on the grounds of the difficulty in “catching up” is represented by any attorney participating in the proceedings in the transferee court on behalf of another party.[20]

Similarly, if the potential tag-along actions are ready for trial, the Panel will not order them transferred.[21] Declining to transfer cases in this situation reflects both the probable lack of benefits to be derived from transfer and the expense and burden that would be imposed on the parties to an action nearly ready for trial in the transferor court.

If the previously transferred actions are no longer pending in the transferee court, transfer of tag-along actions will not be ordered.[22] This result will be mandated if no actions other than the potential tag-along actions are pending, for the prerequisites for transfer under the statute will not be present.[23] Even if there is pending at least one action, however, transfer is not likely due to the minimal value of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.
If the party seeking transfer of a tag-along action has delayed in bringing the motion, the Panel may be especially disinclined to order transfer.[24]

The Panel's fundamental concern when considering the similarity of status of cases is one of balancing the usual benefits of transfer against the possible lack of benefits or overall disruption of proceedings in the transferee court.[25]

Standing to Object to Transfer. The parties to the potential tag-along action clearly have standing to object to transfer of their case. The question has arisen whether parties to other actions may object to transfer. The Panel has determined that parties to any of previously transferred actions still pending in the transferee court may object to transfer.[26] The Panel Rules therefore require that those parties be served a copy of a conditional transfer order relating to a tag-along action.[27]

Familiarity of the Judge with the Actions. One reason the Panel is more likely to transfer cases that are tag-along actions than it is to transfer actions on initial consideration is that the transferee court has had an opportunity to become familiar with the actions. In one case the Panel observed:

Throughout this litigation, we have stressed that the familiarity of the transferee Judge with the class action settlement is an important factor favoring transfer of a tag-along action. And in the event plaintiff is allowed to proceed with his cause of action, transfer will prevent the possibility of duplicating discovery now being pursued in other actions pending in the transferee district.[28]

Nature of Action. The Panel probably gives some consideration to the type of potential tag-along action. The factors applicable to the initial decision are undoubtedly applicable to the tag-along decision. Once actions have been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, transfer of additional actions becomes more likely. The Panel has shown in increased propensity to transfer even dissimilar actions as tag-along actions or as part of separate MDL proceedings.

Certain factors are likely to become even more important in the context of tag-along actions. For example, if new class action is filed, the Panel may be especially likely to transfer it for coordination or consolidation with an earlier filed and transferred class action.[29]

Actions of Transferee Court. The transferee court's actions in handling the cases previously transferred may have an impact on the Panel's action on potential tag-along actions. In one case the tag-along actions before the Panel were claims of one of the parties in the previously transferred cases against other parties. The transferee court had considered and denied a motion to permit the claims to be asserted as part of the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings before that judge. The Panel subsequently refused to transfer the claims when filed as separate lawsuits, noting:

When Judge Becker denied leave to file the cross-claim in the MDL-123 actions, he found that permitting such leave would result in “untimeliness and prejudice as a matter of fact” to the distributors and the other parties in the litigation. The Panel has long recognized that the successful use of Section 1407 can only occur in an atmosphere of trust, confidence, comity and good will among the district courts and the Panel. In light of Judge Becker's ruling, we find that transfer of Skyways under Section 1407 would undercut that atmosphere in the context of this docket. As transferee judge, Judge Becker has a special vantage point with respect to the conduct of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings, and we give great weight to his determination that inclusion of the Skyways claims in the litigation in the transferee district would be contrary to the interests of justice.[30]

Invalid Arguments. The Panel will not consider arguments against transfer based on a party's dissatisfaction with either the past or anticipated rulings of the transferee court.[31] This view of the Panel is consistent with the Panel's general rejection of such arguments and motivations.[32] There is no reason for the Panel to be more receptive to the argument as it relates to tag-along actions.

The Panel also is not inclined to defer transfer of tag-along actions based on the fact there are motions pending in the transferor court.[33] This result as to tag-along actions reflects the Panel's approach to this issue at the time of initial transfer.[34] The fact that the parties have included a forum-selection clause in their contract does not prevent the Panel from ordering transfer.[35]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
J.P.M.L. R. l.1. The Panel Rules are reprinted in their entirety in § 4:34.
See In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger, 333 F. Supp. 911 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
333 F. Supp. at 912.
See In re International House of Pancakes Franchise Litigation, 343 F. Supp. 948 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
In re Ford Motor Co. Crown Victoria Police Interceptor Products Liability Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
See In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., Tires Products Liability Litigation, 151 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2001).

See In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 379 F. Supp. 989, 992 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (Second Opinion and Order dated May 21, 1974). Accord In re Cement and Concrete Antitrust Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1299, 1300 (J.P.M.L. 1979) (actions brought by five states transferred).
See In re Swine Flu Immunization Products Liability Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 648, 649–50 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 559, 560 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
Schweninger v. Walston & Co. (In re Four Seasons Sec. Litigation), 344 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See, e.g., In re Petroleum Products Antitrust Litigation, 476 F. Supp. 455, 458 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
In re Mack Trucks, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 1400, 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

Giuliano v. MB Solutions Second Acquisition Corp. (In re National Arbitration Forum Trade Practices Litigation), 729 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Haven Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 396, 398 (J.P.M.L. 1976).

See, e.g., In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 830 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (accepting transferee court's suggestion to cease transferring additional actions because backlog prompting centralization resolved); In re Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 818 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (Panel notes that docket centralized in 2009, dozens of additional actions added, but now set for trial and denied additional transfer.); In re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 393, 396 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
This requirement for transfer is discussed in § 5:6.
See In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1400, 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See In re Magic Marker Securities Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 862, 865 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See, e.g., In re Koratron Patent Litigation, 327 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
327 F. Supp. at 560.

See In re Motion Picture Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 479 F. Supp. 581, 590 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 441 F. Supp. 930, 932 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 574, 576 (J.P.M.L. 1973). Accord In re Ortho Pharmaceutical “Lippes Loop” Products Liability Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 1073, 1074 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (parties represented pretrial proceedings complete in one action, trial date set in another); In re Helicopter Crash Near Cameron, La., 443 F. Supp. 1022, 1023 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (final pretrial conference trial date set).
See In re Air Crash Disaster Near Upperville, Va. on December 1, 1974, 430 F. Supp. 1295, 1297 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
The requirement of multiple pending actions is discussed in § 3:8.
See In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 159, 162 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (Panel noted 6-year pendency of underlying action and over 2-year pendency of tag-along action).
See In re Motion Picture Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 479 F. Supp. 581, 590 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See, e.g., In re Grain Shipments, 319 F. Supp. 533, 534–35 (J.P.M.L. 1970); In re IBM, 316 F. Supp. 976, 976–77 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
J.P.M.L. R. 7.1(b). The Panel Rules are reprinted in their entirety in § 4:34.
In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 373 F. Supp. 975, 976 (J.P.M.L. 1974).

See, e.g., In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1253, 1255 (J.P.M.L. 1974), judgment aff'd, 577 F.2d 910 (5th Cir. 1978), cert. denied, 439 U.S. 1072, 99 S. Ct. 843, 59 L. Ed. 2d 38 (1979); In re Hotel Telephone Charge Antitrust Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 771 (J.P.M.L. 1972). The Panel's treatment of class actions and, particularly, the role of potentially conflicting class actions in the transfer decision is discussed in § 5:24.
In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 159, 162 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (footnote and citation omitted).
See, e.g., In re Air Crash Disaster at Paris, France, on March 3, 1974, 386 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
This factor as it relates to initial transfer is discussed in § 5:41.

See, e.g., In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Pharmaceutical Industry Average Wholesale Price Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., Tires Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Vioxx Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 1996 WL 143826 (J.P.M.L. 1996) (transfer not delayed to allow transferor court to consider pending motions to remand to state court).
This issue is discussed in § 5:40.
In re Park West Galleries, Inc., Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2009).
